xxl.core.cursors.groupers
Class NestedLoopsGrouper<E>

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor<Cursor<E>>
      xxl.core.cursors.groupers.NestedLoopsGrouper<E>
Type Parameters:
E - the type of the elements returned by the input iteration.
All Implemented Interfaces:
Iterator<Cursor<E>>, Cursor<Cursor<E>>
Direct Known Subclasses:
NestedLoopsGrouper
public class NestedLoopsGrouper<E>
extends AbstractCursor<Cursor<E>>

A nested-loops implementation of the group operator, i.e., all elements of the input iteration get partitioned according to a user defined function. Depending on the specified memory size and object size as many elements as possible will be inserted into temporal bags. Each bag refers to a special key stored in a map in main memory. If enough main memory is available the bags used to store the elements may also reside in main memory, otherwise they should be located on external memory. A key, a bag refers to, is returned when the user defined unary mapping function is applied to an element of the input iteration. If the map's size gets larger than 

     maxTuples = ((memSize - objectSize) / keySize) - 1
the remaining elements of the input iteration are temporary stored in a queue that is typically resided in external memory.

Note: If the input iteration is given by an object of the class Iterator, i.e., it does not support the peek operation, it is internally wrapped to a cursor.

Example usage (1): 

   NestedLoopsGrouper<Integer> grouper = new NestedLoopsGrouper<Integer>(
       new Enumerator(21),
       new Function<Integer, Integer>() {
           public Integer invoke(Integer next) {
               return next % 5;
           }
       },
       new TreeMap(),
       32,
       4,
       8
   );
 
   grouper.open();
 
   while (grouper.hasNext()) {
       Cursor<Integer> nextGroup = grouper.next();
       System.out.print("Next group: ");
       while (nextGroup.hasNext())
           System.out.print(nextGroup.next() + " ");
       System.out.println();
   }
 
   grouper.close();
The enumerator shown in this example delivers the integer numbers from 0 to 20. The main memory size is set to 32 bytes and the object size to 4 bytes. The size of a key for an element is unrealistically set to 8 bytes. So the tree-map used to store the keys in main memory can hold two elements. Therefore only two list-bags returned by the default factory method can be allocated by a call to hasNext.
Due to the fact that not all keys can be stored in the main-memory map the remaining elements that cannot be stored in the two allocated bags will be stored in an array-queue returned by the default factory method. Normally this queue should be placed in external memory. The mapping function maps an element of the input iteration to a certain key. In this case it is realized as: (integer value) modulo 5. So the output is: 
     Next group: 0 5 10 15 20
     Next group: 1 6 11 16
     Next group: 2 7 12 17
     Next group: 3 8 13 18
     Next group: 4 9 14 19

See Also:
Iterator, Cursor, HashGrouper, SortBasedGrouper

Constructor Detail

NestedLoopsGrouper

public NestedLoopsGrouper(Iterator<? extends E> input,
                          Function<? super E,? extends Object> mapping,
                          Map<Object,Bag<E>> map,
                          int memSize,
                          int objectSize,
                          int keySize,
                          Function<?,? extends Bag<E>> newBag,
                          Function<?,? extends Queue<E>> newQueue)
                   throws IllegalArgumentException
Creates a new nested-loops grouper. Determines the maximum number of keys that can be stored in the main memory map: 
     ((memSize - objectSize) / keySize) - 1
This formula is based on the assumption that only the keys, i.e., the map, is stored in main memory whereas the bags storing the input iteration's elements are located in external memory.

Parameters:
input - the input iteration delivering the elements to be grouped.
mapping - an unary mapping function returning a key to a given value.
map - the map which is used for storing the keys in main memory.
memSize - the maximum amount of available main memory (bytes) for the map.
objectSize - the size (bytes) needed to store one element.
keySize - the size (bytes) a key needs in main memory.
newBag - a parameterless function returning an empty bag.
newQueue - a parameterless function returning an empty queue.
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if not enough main memory is available.

NestedLoopsGrouper

public NestedLoopsGrouper(Iterator<? extends E> input,
                          Function<? super E,? extends Object> mapping,
                          Map<Object,Bag<E>> map,
                          int memSize,
                          int objectSize,
                          int keySize)
                   throws IllegalArgumentException
Creates a new nested-loops grouper. Determines the maximum number of keys that can be stored in the main memory map: 
     ((memSize - objectSize) / keySize) - 1
This formula is based on the assumption that only the keys, i.e., the map, is stored in main memory whereas the bags storing the input iteration's elements are located in external memory. Uses default factory methods for list-bags and array-queues.

Parameters:
input - the input iterator delivering the elements to be grouped.
mapping - an unary mapping function returning a key to a given value.
map - the map which is used for storing the keys in main memory.
memSize - the maximum amount of available main memory (bytes) for the map.
objectSize - the size (bytes) needed to store one element.
keySize - the size (bytes) a key needs in main memory.
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if not enough main memory is available.
Method Detail

open

public void open()
Opens the nested-loops grouper, i.e., signals the cursor to reserve resources, open the input iteration, etc. Before a cursor has been opened calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Therefore open must be called before a cursor's data can be processed. Multiple calls to open do not have any effect, i.e., if open was called the cursor remains in the state opened until its close method is called.

Note, that a call to the open method of a closed cursor usually does not open it again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

Specified by:
open in interface Cursor<Cursor<E>>
Overrides:
open in class AbstractCursor<Cursor<E>>

close

public void close()
Closes the nested-loops grouper. Signals it to clean up resources, close queues and cursors, etc. After a call to close calls to methods like next or peek are not guarantied to yield proper results. Multiple calls to close do not have any effect, i.e., if close was called the nested-loops grouper remains in the state "closed".

Specified by:
close in interface Cursor<Cursor<E>>
Overrides:
close in class AbstractCursor<Cursor<E>>

hasNextObject

protected boolean hasNextObject()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.) Inserts as many elements as possible in bags determining a bag for each element by invoking the mapping function. The returned key is stored in the main memory map and the element is inserted in the appropriate bag. If no bag exists for a key, a new bag is allocated. If the map's size is greater or equal to maxTuples the remaining elements of the input cursor are inserted into a temporal queue, which delivers the input elements when the bagIterator has completely been traversed. The bagIterator contains the elements that will be returned by calls to next or peek.

Specified by:
hasNextObject in class AbstractCursor<Cursor<E>>
Returns:
true if the nested-loops grouper has more elements.

nextObject

protected Cursor<E> nextObject()
Returns the next element in the iteration. This element will be accessible by some of the cursor's methods, e.g., update or remove, until a call to next or peek occurs. This is calling next or peek proceeds the iteration and therefore its previous element will not be accessible any more. Returns the next group delivered by the bagIterator, a cursor, and removes the corresponding bag from the map.

Specified by:
nextObject in class AbstractCursor<Cursor<E>>
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.

reset

public void reset()
           throws UnsupportedOperationException
Resets the cursor to its initial state such that the caller is able to traverse the underlying data structure again without constructing a new cursor (optional operation). The modifications, removes and updates concerning the underlying data structure, are still persistent.

Note, that this operation is optional and might not work for all cursors.

Specified by:
reset in interface Cursor<Cursor<E>>
Overrides:
reset in class AbstractCursor<Cursor<E>>
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset operation is not supported by the nested-loops grouper.

supportsReset

public boolean supportsReset()
Returns true if the reset operation is supported by the nested-loops grouper. Otherwise it returns false.

Specified by:
supportsReset in interface Cursor<Cursor<E>>
Overrides:
supportsReset in class AbstractCursor<Cursor<E>>
Returns:
true if the reset operation is supported by the nested-loops grouper, otherwise false.

main

public static void main(String[] args)
The main method contains some examples to demonstrate the usage and the functionality of this class.

Parameters:
args - array of String arguments. It can be used to submit parameters when the main method is called.
